Expectation1: Perform maintenance and cleaning of the machines to ensure optimal performance
Situation1: Routine servicing is scheduled next week during a planned shutdown.
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story: I glanced at the maintenance schedule pinned to the wall, my name circled in red for next week’s shutdown. The machines would be silent, the perfect time to clean and tune every gear and belt. My supervisor expected nothing less than flawless performance—no delays, no excuses. Yet, tucked in my pocket was a small slip of paper, a reminder from my sangha: “Ten minutes of quiet, every day.” Next week, they planned a group meditation, a rare chance to sit together in stillness, just as the shutdown began. I could already hear the hum of expectation from both sides—my supervisor’s sharp eyes, my teacher’s gentle encouragement. I felt the tension coil in my chest. Could I step away from the machines, even briefly, without letting someone down? The thought of missing the meditation left me uneasy, but so did the idea of neglecting my duties. I stood in the workshop, the scent of oil and metal mixing with the memory of incense, torn between the clamor of responsibility and the call to quiet.
